description:
The third season of Mob Psycho 100.

The appearance of a divine tree and new religion turns Mob and Reigen's city upside down!

(Source: Crunchyroll)
synonyms: ม็อบไซโค 100 คนพลังจิต ภาค 3

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Cult
tags.description: Features a social group with unorthodox religious, spiritual, or philosophical beliefs and practices.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Ghost
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a ghost.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Satire
tags.description: Prominently features the use of comedy or ridicule to expose and criticise social phenomena.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: School Club
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a school club scene.

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Surreal Comedy
tags.description: Prominently features comedic moments that defy casual reasoning, resulting in illogical events.

tags.name: Slapstick
tags.description: Prominently features comedy based on deliberately clumsy actions or embarrassing events.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

tags.name: Rural
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the countryside.

tags.name: Demons
tags.description: Prominently features malevolent otherworldly creatures.

node.description:
**[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ONE_rakugaki)** | **[Website](http://galaxyheavyblow.web.fc2.com/)**

One (often stylized as ONE) is a manga artist, best known as the author and creator of [One-Punch Man](https://anilist.co/manga/85364/One-Punch-Man/) and [Mob Psycho 100](https://anilist.co/manga/85189/Mob-Psycho-100/).

He grew up in Konosu, Saitama, and started getting interested in manga when his parents bought him [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/manga/32435/Crayon-Shinchan/). ONE also made several manga in the past that never got serialized such as "Sun Man" and "Tennis Player Ryu".

ONE started releasing One-Punch Man on his own website under no official publisher. [A web version](https://anilist.co/manga/74347/One-PunchMan/) was later serialized by Weekly Young Jump with [Yusuke Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/96903/Yusuke-Murata) as the artist. Mob Psycho 100 was serialized in Ura Sunday, the online version of Weekly Shonen Sunday.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/usagi_rakuda) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/立川譲)

After graduating from university in 2007, Tachikawa joined [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) where he debuted as an episode director on [Kiba](https://anilist.co/anime/845/)'s final episode. After this he went freelance.

Some years later in 2013, Tachikawa created, wrote and directed [Death Billiards](https://anilist.co/anime/14353/), a short film produced by Madhouse as part of Young Animator Training Project's; Anime Mirai, a project which funds young creators and animators. Two years later, Tachikawa got to turn the idea into a 12-episode TV series titled [Death Parade](https://anilist.co/anime/20931/).

He has since gone on to direct works such as [Mob Psycho 100](https://anilist.co/anime/21507/) and [Detective Conan: Zero the Enforcer](https://anilist.co/anime/100653/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%8B%A5%E6%9E%97%E5%92%8C%E5%BC%98)

**Kazuhiro Wakabayashi** is a Japanese sound director who was formerly affiliated with Techno Sound and Omnibus Promotion. After going freelance, he established his own sound production studio on May 7, 2004 called Fonishia. In 2013, he went freelance once again after his sound production studio disbanded.

[Website](http://www.kenjikawai.com/index_e.html) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B7%9D%E4%BA%95%E6%86%B2%E6%AC%A1)

After dropping out of a nuclear engineering program at Tokai University, Kawai Kenji began studying music at Shobi Music Academy. However, he dropped out after half a year. With a few friends, he created the band Muse, playing fusion rock and participating in music competitions. Through competing in such contests, the band members became technically competent to enter the music industry and decided to part ways.

After leaving Muse, Kawai Kenji began composing music for commercials in his home studio. While recording music for [Yuji Mitsuya](https://anilist.co/staff/95874/) he met music director Naoko Asari, who advised him to compose anime soundtracks. Some of his most famous anime soundtracks can be found in [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1288/), [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/), [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/), [Fate/Stay Night](https://anilist.co/anime/356/), [When They Cry](https://anilist.co/anime/934/) and more recently in [Mob Psycho 100](https://anilist.co/anime/21507/).

He has worked on several projects with the director [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/) and has written scores for all of Hideo Nakata's films. Kenji Kawai's music has received the Annie award and Hong Kong Film Award in 2005, for [Ghost in The Shell 2: Innocence](https://anilist.co/anime/468/) he was nominated for an Annie award.

Following his success as an anime music composer, he became involved in live action movies. He contributed music to horror films: Ring, Ring 2, Dark Water, Japanese-Polish science-fiction film Avalon and the Hong Kong film Seven Swords.

For the music found in Seven Swords and A Battle of Wits he was nominated for Best Original Film Score Awards at both the 25th and 26th Hong Kong Film Awards in 2006 and 2007.

(Source: AniDB)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/135960980) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=yoshimichi_kameda)

After graduating from the Department of Fine Arts, Faculty of Art and Design, Onomichi City University he joined studio [AIC](https://anilist.co/studio/48/). 
Currently affiliated with [WIT Studio](https://anilist.co/studio/858).

His animation bears heavy influence from [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/) with the added aspect of *Sumi-e* brush painting techniques, resulting in very characteristic lineart. He first attracted attention with his work on [Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood](https://anilist.co/anime/5114/).

Married to [Maiko Okada](https://anilist.co/staff/138501).

**[Twitter](https://twitter.com/editzhirose)** | **[Website](http://www.editz.jp/)**

**Hirose Kiyoshi** is a Japanese editor and film editor.

**[SOUND BOX Profile (JP)](http://www.sound-box.jp/information/shizuo_k.html)** | **[SOUND BOX Profile (EN)](http://www.sound-box.jp/english/information/shizuo_k.html)**

Shizuo Kurahashi is a Japanese sound effects editor. He worked as an editor at the Nikkatsu filming studio. After that he started his sound career in ToyoOnkyo. 

He established his own company SOUND BOX in 1988. Since 1983, when the dolby stereo system got popular in Japan - he has been creating filmsounds. He has edited and arranged sounds for over 1000 works.

__Mob Choir__ is a Japanese seiyuu collaboration made for the anime [Mob Psycho 100](https://anilist.co/anime/21507/Mob-Psycho-100/), who performed the song "[99](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bw-5Lka7gPE)", which was used as the opening theme to the show. 

The collaboration also reappeared for its sequel [Mob Psycho 100 II](https://anilist.co/anime/101338/Mob-Psycho-100-II/), to perform the song "[99.9](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=epZaT8B31-g&t=2s)" which was once again used as the opening theme to the show, but this time the opening featured Japanese music group [Sajou no Hana](https://anilist.co/staff/137163/sajou-no-hana).

He works for Warner Entertainment Japan. Previously a long-time employee of Geneon Universal, being a part of the company since Geneon was still known as Pioneer LDC. Note: Not to be confused with the CG animator Akihiro Kawamura (川村晃弘)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/南雅彦) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masahiko_Minami)

A founder and representative director of studio [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/). Also the leading producer of its Studio B.

After graduating from Osaka University of Arts, Minami joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) in 1984. There he did desk work and served as a production assistant on many of [Masuo Ueda](https://anilist.co/staff/148840/)'s productions. He was promoted to producer on [Musha Knight Commando](https://anilist.co/anime/9087/) in 1991, and from there he went on to produce shows such as [Mobile Fighter G Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/96/), [Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/) and [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/). In 1998, he left Sunrise and established Bones with [Toshihiro Kawamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/103531/) and the late [Hiroshi Ousaka](https://anilist.co/staff/107410/). He was elected as the representative director of the studio and has held the position since.

Minami's classmates at university included [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Hiroyuki Yamaga](https://anilist.co/staff/100988/), and [Kazuhiko Shimamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/97479/). He appears as a character in the manga [Aoi Honoo](https://anilist.co/manga/55292/), which Shimamoto wrote about his own university days. The manga also received a TV drama adaptation, in which Minami was portrayed by actor Kaname Endou.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/南雅彦) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masahiko_Minami)

A founder and representative director of studio [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/). Also the leading producer of its Studio B.

After graduating from Osaka University of Arts, Minami joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) in 1984. There he did desk work and served as a production assistant on many of [Masuo Ueda](https://anilist.co/staff/148840/)'s productions. He was promoted to producer on [Musha Knight Commando](https://anilist.co/anime/9087/) in 1991, and from there he went on to produce shows such as [Mobile Fighter G Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/96/), [Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/) and [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/). In 1998, he left Sunrise and established Bones with [Toshihiro Kawamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/103531/) and the late [Hiroshi Ousaka](https://anilist.co/staff/107410/). He was elected as the representative director of the studio and has held the position since.

Minami's classmates at university included [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Hiroyuki Yamaga](https://anilist.co/staff/100988/), and [Kazuhiko Shimamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/97479/). He appears as a character in the manga [Aoi Honoo](https://anilist.co/manga/55292/), which Shimamoto wrote about his own university days. The manga also received a TV drama adaptation, in which Minami was portrayed by actor Kaname Endou.

(Source: Wikipedia)
**Ogisu Hirotsugu (小岐須泰世)** is a Japanese producer.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/135960980) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=yoshimichi_kameda)

After graduating from the Department of Fine Arts, Faculty of Art and Design, Onomichi City University he joined studio [AIC](https://anilist.co/studio/48/). 
Currently affiliated with [WIT Studio](https://anilist.co/studio/858).

His animation bears heavy influence from [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/) with the added aspect of *Sumi-e* brush painting techniques, resulting in very characteristic lineart. He first attracted attention with his work on [Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood](https://anilist.co/anime/5114/).

Married to [Maiko Okada](https://anilist.co/staff/138501).

title.native: モブサイコ100 REIGEN ～知られざる奇跡の霊能力者～
デッドマウント・デスプレイ
